a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:09): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: how much work would it be to take make a standalone binary utility based on the v.nu/whattf HTML5 datatype library?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:10): would it be practical at all to try to do so?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:10): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: do you mean a .jar that anyone could load into Jing or MSV?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:11): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: or a utility that includes Jing, too?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:11): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: you should copy <address>, not <div>
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:13): afaict it is identical to <div> apart from foreign content mode
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:13): <div> is scoping
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:13): checks if address is
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:13): <address> and <div> have different WebKit parsing behavior in a way that I don't actually understand at the moment
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:16): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: as far as I can tell, the new structural elements have the exact same tree builder dispatch bits as <address>
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:16): (by inspection of code I've written earlier, not by inspecting the spec)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:18): http://www.whatwg.org/demos/company-home/ probably shouldn't use flags for languages (in order to be a politically correct good example)

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:22): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: at the risk of making clear how little I understand about the v.nu architecture, I have to ask, Does the datatype library have a dependency on Jing?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:23): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: it doesn't
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:24): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Jing and MSV share interfaces for this stuff, so the datatype library depends on those shared interfaces
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:24): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: OK, so to give you the context for why I'm asking: I would like to have something that could be used with rnv
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:25): rnv is C, right?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:25): yeah, but it has this simple mechanism where you can have it delegate datatype-checking to another command-lined application
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:25): and it has Scheme and stdin/out datatype lib interfaces, IIRC
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:25): right
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:26): I'm talking about the stdin interface
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:26): it should be possible to write a command-line wrapper host that can hold any Java datatype library
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:26): and then compile the HTML5 datatype lib with that host using GCJ to eliminate the JVM startup overhead
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:27): right, that's what I had in mind
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:27): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: http://iso-relax.sourceforge.net/
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:27): looks
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:27): that's the SourceForge copy of the shared interfaces
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:28): oops. maybe I have the wrong URL. sorry
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:28): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: http://sourceforge.net/projects/relaxng/
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:28): that's the one
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:29): http://sourceforge.net/projects/relaxng/files/datatype%20%28java%29/Ver.1.0/relaxngDatatype-1.0.zip/download
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:30): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: yep, found it -- thanks

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:39): Darxus: If you have a DTD-valid XML 1.0 file that doesn't use Namespaces, you can process it as SGML if your SGML pipeline implements Annex K, IIRC.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:40): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: you're scaring me with this stuff
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:40): what the hell is Annex K?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:40): sweet, got it working
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:40): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: it's an annex they made to SGML in order to make XML a subset of SGML
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:40): just have to make tests now
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:41): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: IIRC, it adds the <foo/> stuff to SGML
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:41): I see
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (10:42): so next I'm wondering what Darxus would want to process a document as SGML
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:42): XML processing isn't a subset of SGML processing, though, so the Right Thing happens if the input document is already known to be error-free
